dt: {bc}to exclude, hinder, or prevent (something) by prior occupation or measures
{bc}to prevent the normal trading in (something) by buying or diverting goods or by persuading people to raise prices

dt.t: … {wi}forestalling{/wi} the wheat harvest and selling it at three times its cost …
… he sprang like a cat to the top of the cabin and ran aft. But his pursuers {wi}forestalling{/wi} him, he doubled back across the cabin …

pt: {sc}prevent{/sc} {sc}anticipate{/sc} {sc}forestall{/sc} mean to deal with beforehand. {sc}prevent{/sc} implies taking advance measures against something possible or probable.
{sc}anticipate{/sc} may imply merely getting ahead of another by being a precursor or forerunner or it may imply checking another's intention by acting first.

pt.t: {it}anticipated{/it} the question by making a statement

pt: {sc}forestall{/sc} implies a getting ahead so as to stop or interrupt something in its course.

et: Middle English, from {it}forstall{/it} act of waylaying, from Old English {it}foresteall{/it}, from {it}fore-{/it} + {it}steall{/it} position, stall
shortdef: to exclude, hinder, or prevent (something) by prior occupation or measures
to prevent the normal trading in (something) by buying or diverting goods or by persuading people to raise prices
